page.title: 11West Wratting Area: Concerns
page.content: The National Farmers' Union Guidelines for straw/stubble burning has meant that more stubble will be ploughed into the ground this year, but a smokey haze and charred straw on the wind from stubble burning, still troubles many counties during September.Nevertheless, this is considered by the farmers to be the most effective way of disposing of straw and legislation to deter burning would mean considerable inconvenience and perhaps reduced profits for the farmers. If straw is not burned it has to be ploughed in at the rate of one and a half tons per acre, which has a detrimental effect on the soil, and therefore the following crop. The major pests are pigeons, which peck the shoots of the rape during winter and rabbits which are controlled by the disease mixamatosis.
